rLEATx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Brackish/Salt water type was selected for this species, but since water is selected as a map unit, this should serve to limit this species' model to Brackish/Salt water habitats.  I therefore un-selected water type from the drop-down menu above. MJR 29aug07.

Added FW and SW 120m and 9999 (unlimited) FROM and INTO buffers respectively. MJR 30 January 2008.
This species is highly pelagic (Palmer & Braswell 1995, Wilson 1995, Eckert 1992; Martof et al. 1980). As a result, model was including brackish waters that would not be approriate habitat.  I altered this species' model as a hand model to include only nesting beaches and marine waters. MJR 30 January 2008.

habitat_description:
This species forages in temperate waters, but nests in tropical and subtropical latitudes on beaches of the Indian, Atlantic, and Pacific Oceans. Immature leatherbacks spend their first years completely dependent of tropical waters, while adults move into higher latitudes during the summer and even venture into inshore waters (Eckert 2002; Goff and Lien 1988 (As referenced by Natureserve.org). Primary nesting areas are located in Malaysia, Pacific coast of Mexico and Central America, and the Atlantic shore of northern South America. In fact, the largest population occurs in the western Atlantic (Spotila et al. 1996). Nesting sites are also found in Florida and to a much lesser extent in Georgia. In the Caribbean, nesting usually takes place from northern Costa Rica to Colombia, French Guiana and western Surinam. Other areas include the Brazilian coast, Trinidad, northwestern Guyana, the Antilles, Dominican Republic, and Puerto Rico (Natureserve.org). This species burrows in or using soil.

Most of the time is spent submerged in the open ocean. But, also found near the edge of continental shelf, seas, gulfs, estuaries, and bays. Only approaches land for nesting (Eckert 1992).
